fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an algebraic cellular complex, suppose we can encode the basis sets C_ \bullet such that they have decidable equality, and the maps C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}] are computable, then we say the ACC is effective. Suppose further that C_ \bullet are (computably) finite sets, then we say it is effective of finite type.

An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_ \bullet, with a sequence of functions d : C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}], such that d^2 = 0 is satisfied. When a generator has non-zero coefficient in some d \sigma, the generator is called a face of \sigma.
Note that the generators of these chain groups are canonically chosen as part of the data. So a more accurate definition is a chain complex in the Kleisli category of abelian groups.
Here are the unfinished trees. The links not written is also shown in the backlinks section.

We can construct the associated simplicial fiber bundle of twisted products. This can be expanded to a more simple description. Suppose we have simplicial sets F, B, a simplicial group G with an action G \times F \to F and a twisting function \tau on B. The associated twisted product is defined similarly to twisted products (... left/right!)

Given a pair of chain reductions \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D and \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D', we can construct a reduction from the mapping cone \operatorname {Cone} (f) of a chain map f : C \to C' to (the action of \rho on f).

This is a set of notes on effective homology and algebraic topology. Main references are Constructive Homological Algebra and Applications and Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. We assume basic familiarity with the classical aspects of the theory, although there will also be links within this forest to the relevant concepts.

fr:ul.fr:li: W-bar construction, simplicial principal bundles, twisted products by Simplicial objects in algebraic topology
composition of strong homology equivalence, tensor product, cone, bicomplex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any small abelian category can be realized as a full abelian subcategory of a category of left R-modules for some ring R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic cellular complexes associated with a simplicial set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an (effective) simplicial set X, there are two major algebraic cellular complexes (or chain complexes) we can associate to it. We can consider the free abelian group generated by \Gamma ( \Delta ^n, X) at degree n, where the boundary map is given by an alternating sum of face maps: d_n = \sum _{i=0}^n (-1)^{i} \partial _i. This satisfies d^2 = 0 by the simplicial identities. ALternatively, we can consider only the geometric simplices, regarding degenerate ones are zero. More formally, we quotient out the previous chain complex by the subgroups generated by degenerate simplicies. They are both obviously effective by construction.

The first chain complex is called the non-reduced complex, while the second one is the reduced complex. By the two chain complexes are related by a chain reduction. So we will write C_* X for the reduced complex, leaving no notation for the non-reduced one unless otherwise stated.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an admissible discrete vector field on an algebraic cellular complex (C_k, d), we can generate a chain reduction. It will be computable when the cellular complex is effective.

The DVF partitions the chain groups into a direct sum C_k^{s} \oplus C_k^t \oplus C_k^c, corresponding to source, target and critical cells. We would like to create a reduction to the critical cells only. To do this, we invoke perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction and start with a simpler chain reduction.

Consider the algebraic cellular complex whose chain groups are C_k, but the differential d'( \sigma ) = \pm \tau iff \overrightharpoon { \tau \sigma } is in the vector field, and zero otherwise. The sign is determined as the sign of \tau in d( \sigma ). Hence d' : C_{k+1}^{t} \to C_k^s, and is zero otherwise. Therefore using the characterization of chain reduction as a direct sum with a split exact chain complex, we see that this complex can be reduced to the complex on C_k^p whose differential is identically zero.

Next, we try to perturb d' to d. We need h_{ \rho } \circ (d' - d) to be locally nilpotent, where \rho is the reduction constructed above. h_{ \rho } can be viewed as the inverse of d', as it maps the source cell to the target cell. Expanding the definition, we see that this map transports cells down the discrete field line. Since the vector field is admissible, such a transportation eventually terminates and it becomes zero.

Given a mathematical object X canonically associated with an effective chain complex C_ \bullet (X) (e.g. the normalized chain complex of a simplicial set), it is said to be equipped with the structure of effective homology, if we have a strong homology equivalence C_ \bullet (X) \Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow E_ \bullet, such that E_ \bullet is effective of finite type.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminology of effective algebraic cellular complex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The terminology chosen here differs from that in Kenzo. What we call effective is named locally effective; and what we call effective of finite type is named effective instead.
